newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-TIGER WOODS SETS UP FINAL-ROUND SHOWDOWN WITH LEHMAN.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-TIGER WOODS SETS UP FINAL-ROUND SHOWDOWN WITH LEHMAN.

text.p: Tiger Woods set up a final-round showdown between the 1996 Rookie of the Year and the 1996 Player of the Year by catching Tom Lehman at the season-opening Mercedes Championships on Saturday.

The sensational newcomer to the PGA Tour picked up where he left last season by firing a tournament-low seven-under 65 to grab a share of first place with Lehman, who had led after the first two rounds.

Woods, who began the day trailing Lehman by four strokes, birdied the daunting final four holes at La Costa to reach 14-under-par 202, along with British Open champion Lehman, who carded a third-round 69.
The pair stood five strokes clear of Guy Boros, who shot a two-under 70 to finish at nine under. Fred Couples and Paul Goydos were another stroke back after also recording 70s.
"It could become matchplay on the back nine tomorrow, and everyone knows Tiger's matchplay record," Lehman said. "But I'm no powder puff either, and I've never backed away from a challenge."
The 21-year-old Woods is already seeking his third tournament title since turning professional last August.
"I may be player of the year," said Lehman, "but Tiger's player of the next two decades.
"I'm not sure if I feel like the underdog or what. It's a unique situation, you feel like you're just trying to hold off the inevitable."
Woods set the tone for his challenge early with an eagle on the par-five second hole and added birdies on the fourth, eighth and 10th.
But he missed putts of four feet or less on the 12th, 13th and 14th holes, resulting in two bogeys and a par.
"The two bogeys got me going," Woods said. "They got me more focused."
The result of that heightened focus was his impressive four-birdie finish.
"This is why we play, to get into position to win," Woods said. "I'm thoroughly enjoying it."

If Woods picks up his third title in his ninth PGA event as a professional he will pass the $1 million mark in official earnings. The previous fast sprint the $1 million milestone was by David Duval, who reached the mark in 32 tournaments.
Lehman had led the tournament from the start, but came to the 18th a stroke behind Woods. He sank a 30-foot putt for birdie to regain a share of the lead.
"I really wanted to make that putt. I heard four big roars coming in and it didn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that that meant I was behind."
Woods and Lehman will play together for the first time Sunday.
"I don't know just how good Tiger is because I've never seen him play," Lehman said.
"If I play my best and lose, I'm going to know that there's a new kid on the block who's better than anyone else."
